name: Tour of Scotland Quiz / Test | Europe | 20 Questions

questions.text: The capital of Scotland, Edinburgh. What is the name of the Queen's official residence here?
questions.explanation:
Holyrood House.

	Holyrood lies at the opposite end of the famous Royal Mile from Edinburgh Castle.

questions.text: Travel along the banks of the River Forth to the ancient town of Stirling. On the southern outskirts of Stirling is a village which was the site of a famous battle in which the Scots defeated the English in 1314. What is its name?
questions.explanation:
Bannockburn.

	Robert the Bruce was victorious in one of Scotland`s greatest triumphs.

questions.text: To the Kingdom of Fife, and the town of St Andrews, which is most famous as the "Home of Golf", but is also the site of Scotland`s oldest university. In which year was it founded?
questions.explanation:
1411.

	Prince William was a student here in 2003.

questions.text: Across the Firth of Tay to the city of Dundee. It is nicknamed the City of Discovery after the ship of the same name which was built here and is now a museum on the city`s waterfront. Whose flagship was it?
questions.explanation:
Robert Falcon Scott.

	Scott is also known as "Scott of the Antarctic" due to his ill-fated venture to the South Pole in 1912, when he and his party sadly perished.

questions.text: Along the banks of the Tay to Perth; what is the nickname of this town?
questions.explanation:
Fair City.

	Perth was once the capital of Scotland.

questions.text: County of Angus:  which county town, famous for its bridies, a local variety of the Cornish pasty?
questions.explanation:
Forfar.

	Angus was once known as Forfarshire.

questions.text: County of Angus: we head to the coast and another town famous for a local delicacy, smokies, which are smoked haddock. Which town are we in now?
questions.explanation:
Arbroath.

	Arbroath is actually an abbreviation of Aberbrothock, although you won`t see it called that on any map.

questions.text: The city of Aberdeen enjoyed an economic boom in the 1970s and 80s as a result of which industry?
questions.explanation:
Oil.

	Aberdeen is the "Oil Capital" of the UK due to its proximity to the North Sea oil fields.

questions.text: Along Royal Deeside now to a small town famous for its annual Highland Gathering, when the Queen and other members of the Royal Family attend the Highland Games. Which town is this?
questions.explanation:
Braemar.

	The Queen stays in nearby Balmoral Castle during the late summer months.

questions.text: Which city is the capital of the Highlands?
questions.explanation:
Inverness.

	Inverness was conferred city status in 2000, and is one of the fastest growing places in Scotland.

questions.text: The town of Kirkwall is the capital of which group of islands?
questions.explanation:
Orkneys.

	The largest islands in both the Orkneys and Shetlands share the same name - Mainland.

questions.text: Which town lies in the shadow of Scotland`s highest mountain, Ben Nevis?
questions.explanation:
Fort William.

	Ben Nevis is 4,418 feet high, the highest mountain in Britain.

questions.text: The picturesque village of Luss, crowded with tourists in the summer, stands on the banks of which famous loch?
questions.explanation:
Loch Lomond.

	Loch Lomond has the largest expanse of fresh water in Britain.

questions.text: Scotland`s largest city, Glasgow: its name comes from the Gaelic language, meaning what?
questions.explanation:
Dear Green Place.

	Glasgow built its wealth on ship building, but you won`t find many shipyards there today.

questions.text: The holiday town of Rothesay. This is the chief town of which island in the Firth of Clyde?
questions.explanation:
Bute.

	Rothesay was once the county town of "Buteshire", sadly no longer in existence.

questions.text: Ayrshire and the birthplace of Scotland`s national poet, Robert Burns. Where are we?
questions.explanation:
Alloway.

	Burns died in 1796 whilst still in his thirties.

questions.text: In the southwest corner of Scotland is the port of Stranraer. Which country would you most likely catch a ferry to from this town?
questions.explanation:
Northern Ireland.

	The ferries sail to the town of Larne in County Antrim.

questions.text: This small village is famous for weddings. Eloping couples from England have come here for many years to be married in the Old Blacksmith`s shop. Which village?
questions.explanation:
Gretna Green.

	Because the age of parental consent for marriage is traditionally higher in England than Scotland, English couples have come to Scotland for years to get around this law.

questions.text: The town of Melrose is famous for devising which sport?
questions.explanation:
Rugby Union Sevens.

	The abbreviated version of Rugby is now extremely popular world-wide.

questions.text: We stop off at the County Town of East Lothian. Which town are we in?
questions.explanation:
Haddington.

	There was a famous siege here in 1548 when invading English forces attempted to hold out from a combined Scottish and French army.
